name: CoinFactorization
brief: This deals with Factorization and Updates.
detailed:
This class started with a parallel simplex code I was writing in the mid 90's. The need for parallelism led to many complications and I have simplified as much as I could to get back to this.
I was aiming at problems where I might get speed-up so I was looking at dense problems or ones with structure. This led to permuting input and output vectors and to increasing the number of rows each rank-one update. This is still in as a minor overhead.
I have also put in handling for hyper-sparsity. I have taken out all outer loop unrolling, dense matrix handling and most of the book-keeping for slacks. Also I always use FTRAN approach to updating even if factorization fairly dense. All these could improve performance.
I blame some of the coding peculiarities on the history of the code but mostly it is just because I can't do elegant code (or useful comments).
I am assuming that 32 bits is enough for number of rows or columns, but CoinBigIndex may be redefined to get 64 bits.
algorithms: @algorithm Sparse LU with Markowitz pivot selection @math Chooses pivot (i,j) minimizing (r_i - 1)(c_j - 1) where r_i, c_j are row and column counts in active submatrix. This heuristic minimizes expected fill-in during Gaussian elimination. @complexity O(m^2) worst case, typically O(m * nnz_avg) for sparse matrices

@algorithm Forrest-Tomlin update (when doForrestTomlin_=true) or PFI @math For basis change B_new = B_old + (a_q - a_p) · e_p': Forrest-Tomlin maintains L and updates U with spike elimination. PFI (Product Form of Inverse) appends eta matrices. @complexity O(nnz(column)) for FT update; PFI grows over iterations

@algorithm FTRAN with optional Forrest-Tomlin update preparation @math Solves B·x = b where B = L·U: Step 1: Solve L·y = b (forward substitution) Step 2: Solve U·x = y (backward substitution) @complexity O(nnz(L) + nnz(U)) - exploits sparsity

@algorithm BTRAN using transposed triangular solves @math Solves B'·y = c where B = L·U, so B' = U'·L': Step 1: Solve U'·z = c (forward substitution on U') Step 2: Solve L'·y = z (backward substitution on L') @complexity O(nnz(L) + nnz(U)) - exploits sparsity

methods.name: factorize
methods.brief: Factorize basis matrix from LP basic variable indicators.
methods.detailed:
Performs LU factorization B = L·U of the basis matrix defined by the basic columns of the constraint matrix.
@algorithm Sparse LU with Markowitz pivot selection @math Chooses pivot (i,j) minimizing (r_i - 1)(c_j - 1) where r_i, c_j are row and column counts in active submatrix. This heuristic minimizes expected fill-in during Gaussian elimination. @complexity O(m^2) worst case, typically O(m * nnz_avg) for sparse matrices
methods.return_desc: 0 = success, -1 = singular, -2 = too many basic, -99 = memory

parameters.name: rowIsBasic
parameters.description: Array marking basic rows (>=0 means basic)

parameters.name: columnIsBasic
parameters.description: Array marking basic columns (>=0 means basic)

methods.algorithm: @algorithm Sparse LU with Markowitz pivot selection @math Chooses pivot (i,j) minimizing (r_i - 1)(c_j - 1) where r_i, c_j are row and column counts in active submatrix. This heuristic minimizes expected fill-in during Gaussian elimination. @complexity O(m^2) worst case, typically O(m * nnz_avg) for sparse matrices

methods.name: factorize
methods.brief: When given as triplets.
methods.detailed:
Actually does factorization. maximumL is guessed maximum size of L part of final factorization, maximumU of U part. These are multiplied by areaFactor which can be computed by user or internally. 
 Arrays are copied in. I could add flag to delete arrays to save a bit of memory. If status okay, permutation has pivot rows - this is only needed If status is singular, then basic variables have pivot row and ones thrown out have -1 returns 0 -okay, -1 singular, -99 memory

methods.name: factorizePart1
methods.brief: Two part version for maximum flexibility This part creates arrays for user to fill.
methods.detailed: estimateNumberElements is safe estimate of number returns 0 -okay, -99 memory

methods.name: factorizePart2
methods.brief: This is part two of factorization Arrays belong to factorization and were returned by part 1 If status okay, permutation has pivot rows - this is only needed If status is singular, then basic variables have pivot row and ones thrown out have -1 returns 0 -okay, -1 singular, -99 memory.

methods.algorithm: @algorithm Forrest-Tomlin update (when doForrestTomlin_=true) or PFI @math For basis change B_new = B_old + (a_q - a_p) · e_p': Forrest-Tomlin maintains L and updates U with spike elimination. PFI (Product Form of Inverse) appends eta matrices. @complexity O(nnz(column)) for FT update; PFI grows over iterations

methods.name: replaceColumnU
methods.brief: Combines BtranU and delete elements If deleted is NULL then delete elements otherwise store where elements are.

methods.name: updateColumnFT
methods.brief: Forward transformation (FTRAN): solve Bx = b.
methods.detailed:
Solves the system Bx = b where B is the factorized basis matrix. Uses the LU factors: first solves Ly = b, then Ux = y. Attempts Forrest-Tomlin update if space available.
@algorithm FTRAN with optional Forrest-Tomlin update preparation @math Solves B·x = b where B = L·U: Step 1: Solve L·y = b (forward substitution) Step 2: Solve U·x = y (backward substitution) @complexity O(nnz(L) + nnz(U)) - exploits sparsity
methods.return_desc: Number of nonzeros in result, negative if no room for FT update

parameters.name: regionSparse
parameters.description: Work vector (must start as zero, returns zero)

parameters.name: regionSparse2
parameters.description: Right-hand side b on input, solution x on output

methods.algorithm: @algorithm FTRAN with optional Forrest-Tomlin update preparation @math Solves B·x = b where B = L·U: Step 1: Solve L·y = b (forward substitution) Step 2: Solve U·x = y (backward substitution) @complexity O(nnz(L) + nnz(U)) - exploits sparsity

methods.name: updateColumn
methods.brief: This version has same effect as above with FTUpdate==false so number returned is always >=0.

methods.name: updateTwoColumnsFT
methods.brief: Updates one column (FTRAN) from region2 Tries to do FT update number returned is negative if no room.
methods.detailed: Also updates region3 region1 starts as zero and is zero at end

methods.name: updateColumnTranspose
methods.brief: Backward transformation (BTRAN): solve B'y = c.
methods.detailed:
Solves the transposed system B'y = c where B is the factorized basis. Uses transposed LU factors: first solves U'z = c, then L'y = z.
@algorithm BTRAN using transposed triangular solves @math Solves B'·y = c where B = L·U, so B' = U'·L': Step 1: Solve U'·z = c (forward substitution on U') Step 2: Solve L'·y = z (backward substitution on L') @complexity O(nnz(L) + nnz(U)) - exploits sparsity

parameters.name: regionSparse
parameters.description: Work vector (must start as zero, returns zero)

parameters.name: regionSparse2
parameters.description: Right-hand side c on input, solution y on output

methods.algorithm: @algorithm BTRAN using transposed triangular solves @math Solves B'·y = c where B = L·U, so B' = U'·L': Step 1: Solve U'·z = c (forward substitution on U') Step 2: Solve L'·y = z (backward substitution on L') @complexity O(nnz(L) + nnz(U)) - exploits sparsity

methods.name: updateTwoColumnsTranspose
methods.brief: Updates two columns (BTRAN) from regionSparse2 and 3 regionSparse starts as zero and is zero at end Note - if regionSparse2 packed on input - will be packed on output - same for 3.
